title: aRt + ggplot: exploring radial visualizations
description: Computational art techniques can inform and spice up your data visualizations. A presentation for R-Ladies Johannesburg & Tunis.

title: Radial Patterns in ggplot2
description: A love letter to coord_polar() masquerading as a #rstats zine
contents:
This is my #rstats zine of 30 unique computational art pieces with accompanying code deep diving into radial objects. They are categorized by themes, but the order of completion is also indicated. All of these are created solely using {ggplot2} in R and the zine was created using the {xaringan} package.



fitvids('.shareagain', {players: 'iframe'});

 The art in this project is released under a CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 Creative Commons license. More details of usage can be found there. In summary, you can copy and redistribute and are free to build upon the material as long as you give me credit. However, you cannot use for commercial purposes without contacting me.
Additional InfoLink to PDF VersionSource Code

title: TidyTuesday
contents:
TidyTuesday
TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project in R - hosted by the R4DS Online Learning Community. The intent of Tidy Tuesday is to provide a safe community to practice your wrangling and data visualization skills. I am a regular contributor and all of my visualization are created solely using ggplot() and other extension packages.
All of my contributions + code can be found here.
Some Personal (& Recent) Favorites
Plastic Pollution - Data Source: Break Free From Plastic



Tate Art Museum Acquisitions - Data Source: Tate Art Musuem


Toronto Shelters - Data Source: {opendatatoronto}



Washington Trails - Data Source: WTA


Extinct Plants - Data Source: IUCN Red List



Avatar: The Last Airbender - Data Source: {appa}

title: An Introduction to ggplot2
description: A workshop created for Kaiser Permanente's Division of Research Data Visualization Week.

title: COVID-19 Visualization
description: An infectious disease natural history primer for the public
contents:
Managing the COVID-19 Pandemic Course
U.C. Berkeley School of Public Health has an online, self-paced course to provide the public a comprehensive understanding of the COVID-19 pandemic.
As part of this course, Dr.Â Sandi McCoy gave a lecture regarding proven interventions and and what we know works. To support this presentation, I created a visualization how the natural history of some of the most commonly known pathogens changes the mitigation and control strategies that are effective.



This course can be found here.
